1121895001129091078.text: And finally, please remember that we're building things for people. Blockchains are fundamentally about people. Bits of information have no meaning unless someone's around to make meaning of them. We have to remember that everything we're building has a person on the other side.

1121895000307113985.text: I highly recommend picking up a copy of "The Unbanking of America" if you're at all interested in deploying blockchain apps in the US. There are so many real people with real problems that can be addressed *right now*.

1121894999405355009.text: I think I'm going to cut this thread off off here, but there's so much more I could say about this book. It's a great read and it's got about thirty pages of notes if you're looking for further reading. 5/5.

1121894998549700615.text: College degrees have been devalued. People don't have any money left over to save. Servon points out that there's been an uptick in usage of "alternative" financial services by those typically considered middle-class because banks are screwing them too.

1121894997480157186.text: Servon's other big argument within this book is that we're *all* being screwed by this system. She highlights decreasing incomes and increasing financial insecurity. Millennials, especially, are financially insecure in a way that their parents never were.

1121894996829974529.text: (2) Payday lenders are a symptom, not a cause. We can't fix everything by getting rid of them. We need to create systems that can get credit to people when no one else can get it to them.

1121894995890405376.text: (1) The systems in place for evaluating credit risk are broken. Someone could serve huge populations by creating a better system for rating credit worthiness.

1121894995269771269.text: So the key takeaways in this section:

1121894994649014274.text: As a quick aside, I found it interesting to learn that payday lenders often can't sue borrowers to get their money back and payday loan repayments typically aren't reported to credit agencies. The system effectively relies on honest borrowers.

1121894993801687040.text: She specifically mentions a co-worker who had to take out several payday loans after her car broke down. Had the co-worker not taken out the loan, she likely would've lost her job.

1121894992992194561.text: Servon also talks about the psychological aspects of debt. It's hard to consider the long-term impact of an expensive loan when you're dealing with a stressful situation on your own.

1121894342275272705.text: Unfortunately, Servon argues, the systems that determine who get cheap credit (and who don't) are broken. They're biased and don't take into account enough information. Huge populations have much lower credit scores than they should, and they're paying for it.

1121894341436485633.text: There are a lot of people in the US who can't get cheap credit from "traditional" institutions. Payday lenders provide credit to these people. Again, this might seem fine on its face.

1121894340614340608.text: Can't talk about financial services without talking about payday lenders. Servon has an interesting take here (and it's one I agree with): we can't just blame payday lending businesses, we have to understand *why* that market segment is so big.

1121894339691589632.text: (3) The human touch is often very important when it comes to finances. We're talking about real people who have real problems. Sometimes we need to be able to bend the rules a little bit to account for specific situations.

1121894338844352513.text: (2) People value stability very highly. They'll often take the evil they know over the evil they don't. It's important for people to know that their money will still be around tomorrow.

1121894337787330560.text: (1) People are moving away from banks because banks are trying to screw people over. Transparency is extremely important when a single unexpected expense can put you permanently in the red.

1121894336264798210.text: Check cashing businesses make their money on transparent per-transaction fees. More transactions means more fees. Better relationships with customers means more transactions. Servon describes the deep relationships cashiers often have with their customers.

1121894335396626438.text: Additionally, these "alternative" financial services are often strongly incentivized to maintain good relationships with their customers.

1121894334541062149.text: A lot of people can't afford the uncertainty of bank fees. They'd rather pay more money up-front to services like check cashing businesses than possibly paying significantly more to a bank when they least expect it.

1121894333677035520.text: Other issues, like delays in deposit time for checks or the domino-effect of overdraft fees, can cause irreparable harm to someone who's already financially vulnerable. Of course, that's how banks are making money.

1121894332821397504.text: Since the $25 payment happened first you'd have another $25 left in your account, and then the $75 payment would put you at a -$50 overdraft, right? Wrong. A bank might record the $75 payment first and the $25 payment second, leaving you with two overdrafts.

1121894331990859777.text: Let's look at how debit resequencing works by example. Say you have $50 in your bank account. You make a payment for $25 in the morning and for $75 later in the same day.

1121894331084881920.text: See, banks have been caught using dirty tactics to milk overdraft fees from their customers. Possibly the dirtiest of these tactics is called *debit resequencing*.

1121894330241884161.text: You might feel like the overdraft fee is justified. The account holder spent more than they had and the bank was forced to give out a short-term loan, right? And you might be right, if only banks weren't actively trying to screw their customers into overdrafts.

1121894329394638849.text: Banks really show their colors when it comes to overdrafts. When someone spends more money than they have in their account, they'll typically be charged an overdraft fee. This fee is often in the range of $30-$40.

1121894328333471745.text: Since they're making so much money in fees, they're incentivized to create situations in which account holders have to pay fees. Bank account terms are written in language that's difficult to understand. People are up-sold on accounts they can't afford to maintain.

1121894327653928966.text: Her argument is easy to follow. Banks don't really make their money on interest from deposits anymore. Instead, they're pulling in *billions* of dollars in account fees like overdraft fees and minimum balance fees.

1121894326827614213.text: Servon doesn't pull any punches. She tells us exactly why these people aren't using banks: banks don't care about serving them.

1121894325980413953.text: Sometimes these people, who tend to be financially insecure, can't get a bank account because they're blacklisted by services like ChexSystems. Often, however, they explicitly choose not to use a bank account.

1121894325410062337.text: We're given a window into the lives of real people who've chosen to use financial services outside of traditional banks.

1121894323782594566.text: Servon works as a cashier for a check cashing business and later takes on a position at a payday lender. These experiences form anchors within the book that keep the entire work intriguing and grounded. At less than 200 pages, you're not going to get bored.

1121894322918567936.text: This book is not sterile quantitative research. Servon invokes the legacy of Barbara Ehrenreich and embeds herself directly into several of the businesses she seeks to understand.

1121894321928773633.text: Here's a link to buy the book if you're interested: https://www.amazon.com/Unbanking-America-Lisa-Servon/dp/1328745708/ …. I recommend getting a physical copy so you can write notes!

1121894321026936832.text: Book-review-tweet-thread time! We're looking at "The Unbanking of America" by @LisaServon. It's an interesting work that explores the reasons why people use "alternative" financial services (like check cashing businesses and payday lenders) as opposed to banks.

1039153684725284865.text: If any of these tweets were inaccurate, I'm prepared to retract and correct the inaccuracies.

1039153683181826051.text: Anyway, the summary. PlasmaChain is currently a rebranded version of ZombieChain, a DPOS sidechain. The Plasma Cash extensions to PlasmaChain are not in production, and I think the blog post ("Zombie Battleground Marketplace is ALREADY RUNNING on PlasmaChain") was misleading.

1039153681864826880.text:
So PlasmaChain is ZombieChain renamed. The post goes then states: 

"Here’s the thing: The Zombie Battleground Marketplace is ALREADY RUNNING on PlasmaChain as you read this."

This is *extraordinarily* misleading. This makes it seem like Loom has Plasma running in production.

1039153679125938177.text:
The blog post makes it quite clear that these features have not yet been built:

"Here are some of the features that will be built into PlasmaChain:

- Plasma Cash link to mainnet for native ETH, ERC20, and NFT (ERC721) support"

1039153676546453505.text: According to Loom, the team decided that it made more sense for other Loom projects to use a single marketplace chain, and that this chain would somehow make use of Plasma. As a result, they changed the name of ZombieChain to PlasmaChain *without adding Plasma support*.

1039153674424082435.text: Loom was running their marketplace on top of a DPOS EVM sidechain nicknamed "ZombieChain." ZombieChain was a sidechain, not a Plasma chain. Sidechains and Plasma chains give you fundamentally different security guarantees.

1039153673362923521.text: This has been bugging me for a while so I'm just gonna tweet about it - I think @loomnetwork's blogpost (https://medium.com/loom-network/plasmachain-gamechain-socialchain-the-loom-network-universe-expounded-5c672617a333 …) about "PlasmaChain" was misleading. To the best of my knowledge, Loom does *not* have Plasma in production.

1011933765851963393.text:
The general flow here is:
1. User sends funds to contract's address on Plasma chain.
2. User starts exit through contract, sets a "buy now" price.
3. Other users can buy the exit at the "buy now" price.
4. Buyer receives exit funds once the exit processes.

1006579263603032065.text: We're talking ~300k gas for the simple version and ~30k for the efficient version (not counting base 21k TX fee).

1006578122395824129.text:
Ex.: Simple version of More Viable Plasma does full up-front tx verification.  Efficient version of More Viable Plasma basically offloads verification into a challenge step. 

Efficient is *significantly* more complex from an implementation standpoint, but saves easily 90% gas.

1006577866706841600.text: The tradeoffs between simple & efficient in Solidity can be pretty interesting.

Argument: There is no worry of voter censorship because votes are tallied every 126 seconds. 

Response: We've shown that ABP can pick and choose votes to decide initial BPs. BPs have an incentive to remain BPs. Initial BPs can collude to censor all votes changing BP set.

1005713001616310272.text:
Q: Why would they?
